articles.headline: Israel and Hamas Agree to Swap Prisoners for Soldier
articles.snippet: Israel and Hamas have reached a tentative agreement on a proposal to exchange Palestinian prisoners for Gilad Shalit, an Israeli soldier who has been held since 2006.
articles.abstract: Israel and Hamas have reached a tentative agreement on a proposal to exchange Palestinian prisoners for Gilad Shalit, an Israeli soldier who has been held since 2006.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel and Hamas announced an agreement on Tuesday to exchange more than 1,000 Palestinian prisoners for an Israeli soldier held captive in Gaza for five years, a deal brokered by Egypt that seemed likely to shake up Middle East politics at a time when the region is immersed in turmoil.

articles.headline: Iranians Accused of a Plot to Kill Saudis’ U.S. Envoy
articles.snippet: Federal authorities said they have foiled a plot by men linked to the Iranian government to kill the Saudi ambassador to the United States and to bomb Saudi and Israeli Embassies.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities said they have foiled a plot by men linked to the Iranian government to kill the Saudi ambassador to the United States and to bomb Saudi and Israeli Embassies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States on Tuesday accused Iranian officials of plotting to murder Saudi Arabia’s ambassador to the United States in a bizarre scheme involving an Iranian-American used-car salesman who believed he was hiring assassins from a Mexican drug cartel for $1.5 million.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Scott Shane

articles.headline: A Contradiction in the Cargo
articles.snippet: As they track the imports flowing into the country, the companies that ship and transport retailers’ goods are tempering optimism about the holiday shopping season.
articles.abstract: As they track the imports flowing into the country, the companies that ship and transport retailers’ goods are tempering optimism about the holiday shopping season.
articles.lead_paragraph: Analysts have been raising their predictions for holiday spending ever since the back-to-school shopping season was stronger than most had expected.

articles.headline: Senate Jabs China Over Its Currency
articles.snippet: The bill would require the Commerce Department to impose tough tariffs on certain Chinese goods in the event that China was improperly valuing its currency to gain an economic advantage.
articles.abstract: The bill would require the Commerce Department to impose tough tariffs on certain Chinese goods in the event that China was improperly valuing its currency to gain an economic advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan cross-section of Congress seems to agree that China manipulates its currency in ways that make it harder for many American manufacturers to compete. Where they cannot find alignment is on how best to address that problem, while maintaining America’s relationship with its biggest lender and a major trading partner.

articles.headline: Fed Oversight of Nonbank Financial Companies Is Weighed
articles.snippet: The Financial Stability Oversight Council voted to seek public comment on a proposed rule that laid out the standards by which some financial companies could fall under stricter regulation.
articles.abstract: The Financial Stability Oversight Council voted to seek public comment on a proposed rule that laid out the standards by which some financial companies could fall under stricter regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Financial companies that are not banks but have more than $50 billion in assets and $20 billion in debt could be regulated by the Federal Reserve and required to meet tougher standards, according to a proposed rule issued Tuesday by the nation’s top financial regulatory board.

articles.headline: New iPhone Conceals Sheer Magic
articles.snippet: The iPhone 4S is loaded with dazzlers: faster speed, a camera that takes crisper shots, global reach and transformative voice recognition.
articles.abstract: The iPhone 4S is loaded with dazzlers: faster speed, a camera that takes crisper shots, global reach and transformative voice recognition.

articles.headline: Christie Aligns With Romney, Bolstering Him on the Right
articles.snippet: The backing of a politician popular with Republican conservatives may help give cover to a presidential candidate who has had some trouble with them.
articles.abstract: The backing of a politician popular with Republican conservatives may help give cover to a presidential candidate who has had some trouble with them.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEBANON, N.H. — Mitt Romney on Tuesday won the coveted endorsement of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, gaining a persuasive ambassador to populist conservatives and additional cover against attacks from the  right.

articles.headline: A Year Out of the Dark in Chile, but Still Trapped
articles.snippet: A year after the globally televised rescue of 33 miners in Chile, most are unemployed, many are poorer than before and some are experiencing post-traumatic stress.
articles.abstract: A year after the globally televised rescue of 33 miners in Chile, most are unemployed, many are poorer than before and some are experiencing post-traumatic stress.
articles.lead_paragraph: COPIAPÓ, Chile — After his dramatic rescue from a mine last year, Jimmy Sánchez traveled the world, cruising the Greek islands, visiting Britain, Israel, Los Angeles, Disney World — all paid for by people who were moved by the Chilean miners’ story of courage and perseverance.

articles.headline: Europe Tells Its Banks to Raise New Capital
articles.snippet: The president of the European Commission said on Wednesday that banks should temporarily increase their capital buffers to better withstand the crisis.
articles.abstract: The president of the European Commission said on Wednesday that banks should temporarily increase their capital buffers to better withstand the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European banks need to raise more capital to protect themselves against losses on sovereign debt or politicians will do it for them, the European Union said on Wednesday.

articles.headline: BlackBerry’s Service Hiccups Spread; Five Continents Affected
articles.snippet: The trouble couldn’t come at a worse time for Research in Motion, as the handset maker faces a shrinking market share and agitated investors.
articles.abstract: The trouble couldn’t come at a worse time for Research in Motion, as the handset maker faces a shrinking market share and agitated investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Research in Motion said Wednesday that after three days it was still trying to restore service for BlackBerry customers spanning five continents.
